review_title: Women first culture while Men get marginalised unless you bootlick
pros: You are really just working for the brand name. The Compensation is not competitive.
cons:
Increasingly you might realise the company has a “woman-first” culture. If there are two equally capable candidates who are top performers, the female will be promoted first. This is very prevalent in internal mobility situations as well where you might realise in the top jobs, female candidates only require to meet the minimum criteria for the role to be accepted while males will be required to overcompensate for the same role to be moved forward. This is only for Analyst/Associate positions which generally is very still very junior. If females were in this position, they would be complaining that there is no gender equality. On this end, there must be controls to protect both females and males equality chances and not just conforming to social pressures to blindly give opportunities and chances to female candidates first.

For males to succeed in the company you probably need to bootlick well and play politics right to get promoted. I had a co-worker who was really close to my manager, didn’t contribute anything to the BAU tasks but was promoted twice in 2 years. They were so close such that even the spouse were friends with him. Clearly the promotion came from favouritism perspective.

Pay is not competitive and the firm is not trying to keep you. You will realise this once you start going for interviews for the same role.

pros: Technology is great, work life balance

pros:
Regardless of years of experience, opportunities are given to all. It is up to individuals to own it, move it forward and perform well with the task or opportunity given. 

Merit-based approach. Firstly, individual should do well in what they are hired to do before taking on other tasks. Once you show that you can go beyond what you are hired for, you will be rewarded in terms of promotion and bonus. 

Benefits similar to what you get in other financial institutions.
cons:
Should benchmark salary to market as some analysts and associates are grossly underpaid in comparison to what its peers offer. 

Having a good manager will also determine whether you will get your promotion and opportunities. There are certain managers who only look out for themselves and will not fight for their own team members during appraisal period.

job_title: Corporate Access & Investor Relations in Singapore
pros: They allow junior employees to take on responsibility and get hands on experience.  In other words, you work hard and credit is given to you.  You may be the most junior in the team but you still get to face clients immediately when you're in front office.  You're not just assisting the head of the team.
cons: Politics.  Wonder what senior management have in mind and whether they truly understand what is happening on the ground.  The 'team' culture is not that strong either.  It is good to be self motivated but most of the time, its better to work together with your team mates instead of trying to outshine everyone else.  The event or client etc is more important than trying to show off to others or claim credit.

review_title: More transparency and give staff more layman, simplified directions
pros:
Great reputation company to work in.
Great support from managers to explore beyond the scope of work.
Wonderful colleagues who are encouraging and supportive.
Love some of the dedication some of the staff have where they go beyond their daily job, to form committees to help others within the organization to grow.
cons:
Getting too much of politics to do actual work.
Open desk policy may not necessary be suitable for everyone, can be too noisy to focus and speak clearly on phone or to think of solutions. Luckily the offices now have quiet rooms for one to break out.
Promotion process needs to be reviewed, not everyone is a born salesman. The motto to be visible to higher management and getting sponsorships from directors may not be something everyone is comfortable in, thus support, working committee teams recently formed are good to help one to get there.

pros: You get to work with awesome software engineers around you, and they are generally kind enough to guide you any time you need. You get great exposure to financial industry as well as banking.
cons: I guess the biggest disadvantage is that you don't get as important a person as you would be in a smaller non-banking company. There are just too many awesome people around. Moreover, they value much more business than hard skills, which is not a good thing to a IT professional like me. This is why I decided to quit eventually.

pros: The wider global company is a good working environment, and working in locations outside Singapore can be a good experience
cons:
Untrustworthy and highly ambitious local  management.  Backstabbing, lying and setting individuals and teams up to fail is common.  Manipulation of HR review process by local management is endemic

No effective checks on local management by overseas management, or HR.

Generally poor quality technology hires.  

Businesses are all in UK or New York, and contact with the business is very limited or nonexistent

Intrusive global architecture function which does not listen to developers, and forces inappropriate technology onto projects without taking responsibility for failures

Singapore is treated as an outsource location by the rest of the company and it is an uphill battle to persuade people outside Singapore to take you seriously

pros:
- Great exposure in global setting
- Adequate training to ensure up to speed with your job
- Works are done professionally
- the managers (for certain teams) are really nice and there is no hierarchy barrier
- good benefits and welfare
cons:
- Work life balance is hard to find for certain departments
- Uncertainty for those on contracts - There is some colleagues who has been on contract basis for more than 2 years
- Hard to be promoted, but understadable in such challenging environment
- no much action taken to target those staffs who are under performing and pulling team performance

pros: Good benefits with people from diverse background and a variety of experience. In general, most of the employees are experienced and work with the company for a very long period of time. The senior management generally knows each individual at the company.
cons: Long working hours like any other bank. Systems are a bit backward and certain things are still manual which is unexpected for such a prestigious bank.

review_title: Great company run by Mr. Dimon
pros: Great place to work for where you are given accountability with responsibility.
cons: The leadership has changed in a very big way to the extent you are unable to recognize the organization pre and post the financial crisis.

pros: They promote the new and junior staff which is good for them. They are able to get hands-on experience. If you are a hard-worker, you get your due, its not dependent on the level.
cons: There is lot of politics, you never know what the senior management wants. The team work is not too prevalent and you are not really allowed to outperform the other members. Client is everything.

pros: Great brand value. Good pay. Excellent use of technologies. Cool HR policies and other stuff.
cons: Too big to manage at times. Too much politics. Excessive bureaucracy. Always creating that fear amongst employees to perform or perish. Too many organization reshuffles. As a result ever changing objectives and deliverable.

pros:
1. Good welfare and benefits.
2. Work that is done by only 1 or 2 teams in other banks can be divided into several components in JPM and involve 3-5 different teams. This can be both good (ensure proper process is followed & strong check & balance) and bad (bureaucratic & time consuming to get things done).
cons:
Rather bureaucratic.
Working hours can be long. Night calls can be expected even though majority of the participants of global calls are based in EMEA & APAC (a.k.a. "US-centric").

pros:
Since it's one of the largest banks in the world / US (if not the largest, depending on which metric), they have endless resources for training and really wide opportunities to choose from.
Great salary package and benefits. Almost unparalleled.
Good interest/resources groups with great opportunities for networking and connecting
cons:
- Too US centric. Being in Singapore which is 12/13 hours ahead, too many late night calls and too many late replies to emails.
- Since it's big, even too big, experience really depends on the team. There's no standard. People are clamouring to be seen.

job_title: Home Lending Advisor in Columbus, OH
pros: Learn the industry, if you drink the “cool aid”, and don’t make ANY opinions known, (or make any observational facts known), you can get into Chase, and possibly move out of this department into a more secure, appreciated role.
cons: Poorly competitive base salary. $36,000/annually. Doesn’t increase, regardless of performance. Compensation sales plan changes significantly, requiring significantly more closed contracts per month, to make less money. They increase administrative responsibilities on the sales team, which takes time out of performing business building tasks, that you would get paid on. Service compensation is poorly tied to your service scores. They refuse to update surveys, to isolate which roles in the process provided the service that was good in contrast to where it was challenged. There is only ONE Service Score on the post mortgage contract closing survey. Operations is poorly compensated, so those roles that close the mortgage contract, don’t get a financial “ding”, if they perform poorly. There is no incentive for operations to get their job done, when they are out sick, vacation, or on leave. Their team managers, are over taxed, and can’t possibly get to everyone on their team that they need to cover. You can’t have operations so poorly conducted, and get poor service scores, then make the sales team suffer by not receiving CSAT bonus. MANY individuals in sales and operations are being treated for anxiety, medically. Was told by individuals personally, the meds, and sleep issues they were experiencing in their role.

job_title: Business Analysis and Reporting Specialist in Warsaw, Masovia
pros:
- good localization, close to the metro,
- having JP in our CV, but to be precise we work for a polish branch,
- reimbursement for work-from-home equipment.
cons:
- no life-work balance, 
- not paid overtime, if you want them to be accepted/paid you need to provide an extensive explanation, 
- very long process screening for new joiners, if there is a lack of employees you need to wait even 3-4 months for someone new to join, meanwhile more tasks for you, you work as 1,5-2 persons but get paid as 1 and no one cares, 
- an increase in salary is really low, new joiners have a higher salary than me after my increase, the increase does not cover even inflation,
- many people are multitasking during the calls to not waste any minutes and leave the office at the normal time,
- if you start work at 9 am you have to work until 5:15 pm,
- everyone is overloaded with work, and sometimes there is not really someone to help you, but you have to finish your tasks, work under pressure, 
- partly work is really repetitive, 
- escalation policy, it is causing a stressful atmosphere, 
- supervisors are checking you on every step, adding new tasks, assigning to new projects when you are already overloaded and they don't understand why you are not happy, 
- medicover sport card, 
-even simples tasks require approvals, unnecessary waste of time, 
- you can work only 2 days from home (the best according to work pattern) and only from Poland (no work from abroad- important for foreigners who would like to visit family for longer),
- salary is not competitive, 
- really- a lot of work, and more and more with every month,
- small possibility to grow,
- working close with India, they are terrible to work with, many difficulties in communication, some of them never saw SAP before, do not know how to work in Excel so you have to teach them such things, and they are favored over Poland Teams! their mistakes are not that easy escalated as Poland's Team, 
- managers are just using you to get work done, they do not have to do any of the team's tasks so why they should do that, better to give you more and check if you finished on time.

I have seen this grotesque person put people down for what they are wearing, how they look, their views and indeed anything this nasty individual can pick on. Ruling by fear and it has to stop immediately. 

Why is she here? I am sure that if JP bothered to ask, the above is incredibly easily verified. As the start of your career with JP this is first impression which is concerning

Previous places of employment are well known for the bad reps they have and this ogre was front and centre. 

Queue the tears when this is read, along with a healthy dose of explaining how excellent the rep is (laughable). There will be the anger and fake outrage but all that is written here is true. If there is any doubt however, Bournemouth has at least a thousand people who can confirm this.

review_title: They promote and pay idiots not talent
pros: Exposure to lots of tech
cons: If you have great talent, produce superior results, it does not necessarily translate to a promotion and more pay. They base promotions and pay on how well they like you. I've been in my position almost a decade and have only been promoted once. I was hired as a contractor almost 10 years ago and I'm barely making $3k more now, than I did when I was first brought on. My accomplishments are numerous and far surpass that of most of the colleagues and managers I've worked under. I've single handedly created solutions that were implemented globally that created millions of dollars in value from automated efficiencies and barely received a thank you. And creating these solutions weren't even apart of my job description, they were just extra curricular for me to build and help other people solve problems faster. Some people with minor results have achieved great success at getting promoted almost annually just cause they are well liked and chat it up nice with managers around the water cooler. But the value these people bring is minimal if not devaluing to those around them that actual do produce. I've seen first hand some managers pass on promoting someone with great accomplishments simply because they did not want to lose their production. The politics here are absolutely ridiculous.

pros: Internal Moves are surprisingly straightforward and easy. Even moves into roles above your Job Grade (though you won't move into that Job Grade and probably won't have any change of comp) with internal moves being plentiful and the ability to work all over the world. Good schemes for Graduates. Working hours during the week are flexible usually and I haven't been made to work past my allocated hours unless for major production issues. Pay is fairly good when entering the company and for similar roles. The Grad schemes have a very good pay structure. Depending on the team the work isn't that demanding most of the time Managers are more lenient than they should be with poor-quality or slowly delivered work than they should be. This is either a pro or con depending on your situation The interview process isn't a 4 stage ordeal like some other higher prestige tech companies and doesn't revolve solving leetcode questions nor making long presentations depending on the role. This could be a con because some inferior employees sometimes slip through the cracks There are a lot of helpful internal tools. Free Coffee? I don't drink Coffee so I don't care about this one but if you do like Coffee it's a plus. Though I hear it isn't good so people go to Pret/Starbucks anyway. Depending on the LOB there are plenty of Social Events for networking. You will work with talented people usually.
cons: 3 Days a Week in the Office is just stupid when every other Bank has at most 2 days in the office. Though managers are increasingly taking a more liberal view of this policy The 3 days in the office have caused a lot of very talented people to leave and talented developers are not joining. Manager Russian Roulette. Some Managers are really good and some are terrible. A lot of time your team leaders are too busy (too many meetings) to do tasks such as 1-2-1s, and other support. A Mid-Year review basically boiled down to me saying I thought I was doing a good job and that was it. You'll be in a lot of meetings due to most teams being distributed. This can pose difficulties when the same team is spread over time zones. I've been in teams with members in Houston and Mumbai who never overlap in working hours. You will get a lot of emails. A lot of which will have no impact on your job. If you stay in a team long enough it will be moved around organizationally. A lot of managers do not know the HR policy well at all. This results in some minor levels of exploitation as I was not made aware that covering support work for a week constituted a payment. This went on with my team for years and took 6 months from finding out about this system to be back paid for these activities. Working on Weekends is sometimes expected depending on the team for certain activities. Salary Ranges are deliberately obscured and discussion between employees is taboo. So I imagine a lot of people are underpaid. You're working in a bank so there are a lot of processes to get access to tools to do your job Onboarding documentation is done on a team-to-team basis so you're at the mercy of that team's documentation Periods of benching in certain teams/roles. End-of-Year pay rises and Bonuses have been curbed due to COVID even though the bank has made record profits. From my understanding, you will only get minor rises in pay unless you come with an offer from another company. Furthermore, if you move teams during the team your bonus budget will be shared between both teams. This results in a lot of people getting a cut bonus and has caused at least one person to leave shortly after this. A lot of Cognizant consultants are used and they are at times very bad (though some are really good) I don't understand why it's cheaper to get to 2 consultants when one full-time developer would be better long-term. Internal Job Grade promotions take a very long time to materialize. I would advise that it is easier to leave and get a promotion than move internally. I would estimate it takes about 5 years to move between each Officer Title Assoc -> VP -> ED -> MD. Though I would add that these job titles are tangibly worthless, outside of not getting overtime once you hit VP, and if you want more responsibility/money the best course of action would be to move around. You're not going to be working on "fun" greenfields tech or activities. Developers'roles will mostly be around writing boilerplate Java. Or if you're in the business/project management side combing through Jira or Excel, to plan for said boilerplate Java tasks. One Senior ex-colleague said once he was made redundant that he was happy he didn't need to go into "The Most Boring Office in the World" anymore. Take of that what you will I've been here for over 5 years I think the lifelessness has a certain charm to it. I don't know if this is just the people I work with or me. Still, I find a lot of people to lack emotional or situational intelligence with meetings being canceled last minute or just not attending a meeting that was created for them in mind. Certain decision-making can be obscured and lengthened in certain LOBs because of the amount of middle management in it i.e. Too Many Cooks in the Kitchen If you need stuff done you're better off doing it yourself. A lot of time people will not perform tasks or actions for you unless you have a superior job title to them or bring someone with a superior job title into the conversation. Even people you're meant to be in the same team with. Like many businesses, there is a ton of butt-kissing which at times verges on the embarrassing. Too many talented people, who have better things to do, do not get rewarded properly because of this and leave There is a lot of Regulatory training for financial stuff even if you're in tech. This is almost always half-arsed by every employee. Been in positions where a line manager is responsible for multiple disparate teams within the same organization which don't really collaborate with each other. Which causes the line manager to become extremely stretched and causes issues to slip through the cracks. In some teams, it has been unclear what the exact role of the team is and due to this a team does much disparate Management uses terms such as Agile, DevOps, and SRE but doesn't actually do such tasks. So many Project Managers I've encountered call themselves Agile but don't do Agile properly or at all

review_title: It's a mixed mag. Not for everyone.
pros: Working at JPMC can be good and can be bad. I've never had mixed thoughts about an employer before. Usually it's good or bad, but this one appears to capture a bit of both. Pros: it's a humongous international corporation which is represented in over 60 countries. You have great opportunity to develop your career internationally. You work with great people that become your friends. There are truly amazing understanding and supporting people. It is a pleasure to come to work every day. Compensation and benefits are great. Compensation alone is better than that at many other large financial institutions; however this may vary by position. They have an array of health insurance options to choose from - all are quite attractive. Offices are modern and top notch; however not for everyone - see cons. The organization is very diverse. You'll encounter many different people of all kinds of backgrounds and stances. Really cool.
cons: Cons: Depending on your position, hours can be long and frustrating. A lot of it will depend on tech issues. For some positions, work can be delayed by 2-4 hours or even longer. You will end up sitting around doing nothing because you won't be able to perform your duties. As mentioned above, offices are modern and top notch, but for me, there just isn't enough privacy. No cubicles. Instead, they have what they call "high performance work stations". Those are small desks with a computer and two screens at each. Every one of those got a camera. Chances are you're always on camera - meetings happen quite often. So it's leaving you with almost zero privacy. No picking nose while running queries. The organization is very bureaucratic. You will need approval for everything. Even if you have access to any platform, you will not be able to perform certain operations there. These will require individual requests to be approved by tech people located all over the place. May take weeks to get proper access privileges. Their return to office policy is inflexible and pretty weird. You can't work from home the same days week to week. Instead you must alternate one or both of these days. They didn't specify why only Mondays and Fridays can't be WFH. It's incredibly inconvenient to keep track of both for you and your supervisor.

review_title: Not Woman friendly.  Disorganized. Harmful. D
pros: Salary. Benefits. Company Size. Colleagues on other teams.
cons:
Within J.P. Morgan Wealth Management, Technology, Self Directed Investing specifically the work environment is one where women are few and planning resignations at a dramatically high rate for the number of women working here. The CTO and various male colleagues across ranks (definitely Executive Directors and Vice Presidents across the board) are verbally abusive to women, they don't listen to women and they act like when women bring up fact they are crazy or problematic. Facts don't matter here only what men in positions of power say and do.
You have no choice but to push back and when you do you are blamed for all of their pitfalls.
It is unhealthy and I do not recommend to any woman/womxn to work here. There are many great places as JPM is a great company. This is not it. 
Many women have left and are leaving. So as long as this is the culture it will not be a good place to work.
JPM is a great company and should not be defined by this one space. It has many women in positions of power and positions where they help , mold and cultivate others. Also many men outside of this group who are competent, intelligent, helpful and help others by upholding the code of conduct at the company. Overall an amazing place. This group is not and needs new leadership.

pros: Good ctc but if you negotiate well. Yearly hikes are good too.
cons:
So many-

1) No idea howwww the rating here is 4.1 because it exploits people on an inhuman scale.

2) The manager has no leash and treats you like a slave. Being in JP Morgan will make you realize what a toxic environment is that people keep talking about.

3) So as per the Manager if you take a leave, even if a sick one YOU HAVEEEE TO PICK UP THE CALL else no leave shall be granted in future.

4) This manager insults every member of the team in team meetings in his LOCAL language to get that effect properly.

5) Employees are so scared of losing their job so they dont go to HR and are just leaving after completing a year.

6) WLB is non existing. 6am-2am is the normal.

7) PM has 0 technical knowledge and forces you to get 5-6 tasks in a day which would take 14-16 hrs to complete. If you dont comply there is mental harassment by him constantly calling.

8) Other employees tried complaining in the past to the HR it seems but no action was taken.

9) So HR is just for namesake. Company posts fairytales on employee wellbeing while treating them like slaves.

10) Manager has absolutely no regard for privacy of employees. Calling them day and night and talking to them in threatening tone.

Now comes the major surprise. This is not one off or a particular project. This behaviour is common across aallllllllll projects so changing projects will do you absolutely no good.

JPMC managers should be jailed for harassment.

job_title: Senior Associate Software Engineer in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
In a big company like this alot will depend on your team and manager; so my experience may not be yours. But at least for me, the work life balance is great. I know some people complain they work too much, but I have never felt the compuction to work more then my normal hours, except the odd half hour here or there. I made it known very early on when my day is done im gone. I think people that are doing long hours have trouble laying that line down. 

I have had a lot of opportunities to learn new technologies and work and exciting new projects. Honestly this the best job i've had to date.

The pay and benefits are good as well.
cons:
Bureaucracy can be a bit of an issue here.

Thier forcing us to come back to the office 3 days a week to spite us all working from home successfully for the last 2 years.

Pay here is good, but it could be better.

Getting promoted to VP and above is alot about the people you know.
